newsitem.title: USA: India may still need 1-2 mln T wheat--USDA aide.
newsitem.headline: India may still need 1-2 mln T wheat--USDA aide.

text.p: WASHINGTON, July 16 (Reuter) India appears to have filled its near-term need for wheat, but may still have to import an additional 1.0 to 2.0 million tonnes later this year, a U.S. Agriculture Department official said Wednesday.

"For now, they seemed to have filled their needs--at least for the next few months," Thomas Pomeroy, U.S. agricultural counselor in New Delhi told Reuters. "There's a possibility they might buy a million or two more tonnes, but I don't think they're going to do it for several months."
Pomeroy and other overseas U.S. agriculture department aides are in town this week for an annual conference.
Earlier this year, India bought 2.7 million tonnes of wheat from Australia, Canada and Argentina and expectations were that it would buy as much as 1.5 million tonnes more.
But import plans have been put on hold after cooler-than- usual weather in parts of India this year led to a larger-than- expected wheat crop, Pomeroy said.
The Indian government estimates the domestic wheat crop at 69 million tonnes, compared to USDA office in New Delhi's estimate of 67 million, Pomeroy said.
If India does return to the world wheat market, the U.S. should be in a better position to make sales than it was earlier this year, Pomeroy said.
In early 1997, Australian wheat prices were substantially below the U.S., but that is no longer the case.
Also, the United States has been working to address grain quality concerns raised by the Indian government and remove that issue as a barrier, Pomeroy said.
Even if India does not import more wheat this year, its growing population and economy will require it to import substantial amounts from time to time, he said.
